name: Mons
fun_fact: Fun fact: Mons hosts Festifood twice a year, a culinary festival celebrating haute cuisine and Belgian artisans - but the city's most famous contribution to Belgian cuisine is 'porc Ã  l'Berdouille', created in the 1960s by smothering pork in white wine cream sauce with pickled onions, proving that sometimes the best traditions are surprisingly recent.

hero_dishes.name: Porc Ã  l'Berdouille
hero_dishes.description: Pork chop or fillet smothered in white wine and cream sauce flavored with pickled onions and gherkins - rich, tangy, and uniquely Mons
hero_dishes.origin_story: Created in the 1960s, this dish is an acquired taste that embodies Mons's culinary generosity. The combination of cream, wine, and pickled vegetables creates a sauce that locals swear by
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional Belgian restaurants throughout Mons, local brasseries

hero_dishes.name: Pagnon Borain
hero_dishes.description: Traditional local specialty reflecting the culinary generosity of the Borinage region
hero_dishes.origin_story: This dish represents the hearty, working-class food traditions of the Borinage coal mining region around Mons, where substantial meals fueled hard labor
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional restaurants serving regional Hainaut specialties

hero_dishes.name: Carbonnade Flamande
hero_dishes.description: Flemish beef stew slow-cooked in Belgian beer with onions and spices - rich, sweet, and deeply satisfying
hero_dishes.origin_story: This classic Belgian dish is found throughout the country, but Mons's version uses local beers and is served in generous portions at traditional brasseries
hero_dishes.where_to_find: La Cervoise (charming brasserie in heart of Mons), traditional Belgian restaurants

hero_dishes.name: Prime Beef at La Table du Boucher

hero_dishes.origin_story: Chef Luc Broutard at La Table du Boucher has earned recognition from Michelin, Gault & Millau, and Gastromania by focusing on exceptional meat and seasonal products
hero_dishes.where_to_find: La Table du Boucher (modern brasserie, Michelin-recognized)

signature_drinks.name: Belgian Craft Beer
signature_drinks.description: Local artisanal beers ranging from blonde ales to dark abbey beers
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Paired with traditional dishes at breweries and brasseries. Beer is treated with the same respect as wine in France, with specific beers matched to specific dishes

signature_drinks.name: Belgian Chocolate Hot Chocolate
signature_drinks.description: Rich, thick hot chocolate made from real Belgian chocolate - more dessert than drink
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Sipped slowly at cafÃ©s, especially in winter. Belgium takes its chocolate as seriously as its beer
